greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = numerator of n/(n+20).
comment: Contains as subsequences A026741, A017281, A017305, A005408, A017353, and A017377. - _Luce ETIENNE_, Nov 04 2018
Multiplicative and also a strong divisibility sequence: gcd(a(n),a(m)) = a(gcd(n,m)) for n, m >= 1. - _Peter Bala_, Feb 24 2019
link: Vincenzo Librandi, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..2000
P. Bala, A note on the sequence of numerators of a rational function
formula: a(n) = n/gcd(n,20) is a quasi-polynomial in n since gcd(n,20) is a purely periodic sequence of period 20.

O.g.f. for reciprocals: Sum_{n >= 1} x^n/a(n) = Sum_{d divides 20} (phi(d)/d) * log(1/(1 - x^d)) = log(1/(1 - x)) + (1/2)*log(1/(1 - x^2)) + (2/4)*log(1/(1 - x^4)) + (4/5)*log(1/(1 - x^5)) + (4/10)*log(1/(1 - x^10)) + (8/20)*log(1/(1 - x^20)), where phi(n) denotes the Euler totient function A000010. (End)
program: (Sage) [lcm(20,n)/20 for n in range(0, 80)] # _Zerinvary Lajos_, Jun 12 2009
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, May 15 2005
